item.title: AldiÁöÑ$ 30 HulkenÂåÖÂåÖÊòØ2026Âπ¥‰ª§‰∫∫ÂûÇÊ∂éÁöÑÊñ∞‚ÄúIt‚ÄùÊâãÊèêÂåÖÔºàÂØπ‰∏çËµ∑Ôºå Trader Joe's Ôºâ
item.description:
NYC‚Äôs going head-over-wheels for this year‚Äôs must-have bag ‚Äî and its $30 dupe.¬†

Ariana Rodriguez never leaves her Upper West Side home without her phone, her keys and one of her four Hulken totes. It‚Äôs a $125 foldable, rolling accessory designed to cart everything from groceries to gym gear, from dirty laundry to designer shopping hauls.¬†¬†

And it usurps the throne of the formerly viral Trader Joe‚Äôs tote, rising as the ‚ÄúIt‚Äù accessory of 2026.¬†

‚ÄúI literally bring my Hulken everywhere,‚Äù Rodriguez, 36, a married mom of three and professional vintage procurer, told The Post. ‚ÄúIn New York, you always end up buying a bunch of random stuff. So it‚Äôs just, like, so helpful to have a big, durable bag on wheels that‚Äôs both useful and stylish.‚Äù

The millennial‚Äôs Hulken collection ‚Äî made complete by a mixture of two medium ($110 each) and two large metallic-colored bags ‚Äî is valued at approximately $470.¬†

But shopping addicts and fanatics on a budget, both in the Big Apple and beyond, are rushing to their nearest Aldi supermarkets for the chain‚Äôs $29.99 ‚ÄúFoldable Rolling Tote,‚Äù featuring a Hulken-like look, pull and fab finish.¬†

Representatives for Hulken didn‚Äôt immediately respond to The Post‚Äôs request for a comment.

But Chantel Hailer, director of corporate buying at Aldi, exclusively told The Post that the store‚Äôs cut-rate replica is meant to give patrons a taste of economical elegance.

‚ÄúYou shouldn‚Äôt need a luxury budget to carry your groceries,‚Äù said Hailer. ‚ÄúOur team keeps an eye on what is trending and then works to create luxe products for less.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis bag delivers on both value and design,‚Äù she added, ‚Äúgiving Aldi shoppers what they want and deserve in the Finds aisle, without that luxury markup.‚Äù ¬†

‚ÄúOver $100? Nah,‚Äù Aldi teased in an Instagram post, advertising their wallet-friendly reproduction, which officially hit shelves Wednesday in colors black, silver and rose gold.¬†

And bougie bag buffs are going nuts over the knockoff.¬†

‚ÄúAnyone who is familiar with Hulken bags ‚Äî run, don‚Äôt walk. Aldi is selling a dupe for $29.99,‚Äù raved Amanda, a married New York mom, in a trending video. ‚ÄúI just went to two different locations ‚Ä¶ the second store only had four [bags] left. They‚Äôre perfect.‚Äù

Janelle, a baker based in Philadelphia, also praised the copycat carryall for nearly matching the designer sack‚Äôs allure.¬†

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs actually the exact same dimensions as the medium Hulken. It looks just like it. It‚Äôs moving pretty good,‚Äù said an impressed Janelle after filling the Aldi bag with groceries and testing its wheels on camera. ‚ÄúThis dupe is legit.‚Äù

Mandy, a separate fan of the faux finery, lauded the everyday luggage in a clip of her own, saying, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have a Hulken beat because I refuse to pay that price for a bag ‚Äî I just refuse it. But this is identical.‚Äù

‚ÄúI bought the last two at my local Aldi,‚Äù continued the blond. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so pumped.‚Äù

The Hulken ‚Äî and its more affordable doppelg√§nger ‚Äî is merely the latest carrier to be anointed the hottest commodity in recent times.¬†

Before the Trader Joe‚Äôs tote craze reached a fever pitch in summer 2025, T.J. Maxx‚Äôs $35 ‚ÄúLobster‚Äù purse shone as the most haute status symbol among Gen Z glamour gals ‚Äî some even willing to ‚Äúsell a kidney‚Äù for the crustacean-inspired add-on ‚Äî last April.¬†

Here‚Äôs hoping fashion fiends don‚Äôt resort to hawking organs for this year‚Äôs buzziest bagging gear.¬†
item.author: Asia Grace

item.title: HochulÂàõÁ∫™ÂΩïÁöÑ2600‰∫øÁæéÂÖÉÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∑ûÈ¢ÑÁÆóÊèêÊ°àÁõÆÂâç‰∏çÂåÖÊã¨Â¢ûÁ®é
item.description:
ALBANY ‚Äì Gov. Kathy Hochul won‚Äôt rely on an income tax hike to balance her record-high $260 billion state budget proposal that will be unveiled Tuesday, The Post has learned.

Hochul‚Äôs budget proposal for the 2026-2027 fiscal year will blast past last year‚Äôs $252 billion executive proposal and set the stage for weeks of fights with a Democrat-dominated state legislature that has consistently pushed taxing the rich for the last several years, according to preliminary figures.

‚ÄúOur revenue projections in the current year, thanks to the strength of Wall Street and a progressive tax code, have really provided an outsize level of returns to make the investments, particularly in child care,‚Äù Hochul‚Äôs budget director, Blake Washington, told The Post ahead of the anticipated release of the plan.

A progressive push toward universal childcare ‚Äì in large part led by Democratic socialist New York City Mayor Zohran Mamdani ‚Äì is a big driver in the budget‚Äôs ballooning spending.

Hochul has promised $4.5 billion toward expanding childcare programs statewide ‚Äì¬†a $1.7 billion increase from the current state budget. That will include launching a new ‚Äú2-Care‚Äù program for all 2-year-olds in the Big Apple and $210 million to expand pre-K for 4-year-olds statewide.

But while Hochul‚Äôs proposal helps fulfill a key promise by her newfound ally Mamdani, the governor has pointedly rejected calls to fund it by taxing the rich.

‚ÄúShe thinks it‚Äôs a last resort to raise taxes on anybody at any time,‚Äù Washington noted.

The budget will not increase income taxes, though it will extend the top corporate franchise tax rate of 7.25% that was originally implemented under former Gov. Andrew Cuomo in 2021 and renewed under Hochul in 2023.

Mamdani, for his part, is now pushing the state to hike taxes on high-income earners to fund his freebie-filled agenda including the childcare program. Fiscal watchdogs have warned the city faces combined deficits of $12 billion in the next two fiscal years ‚Äì a potentially damaging blow to his big campaign promises.

Hochul‚Äôs plan will also hike Medicaid spending by an eye-watering 11.4%, which Washington said will include more funding for hospitals after they took a hit as a result of the feds refusing to subsidize spending on some Obamacare-era health care plans.

New York ultimately decided to kick about 450,000 people off its Essential Plan last year as a result of the move, with hospitals crying poverty as they expect to have to pick up the tab when patients show up without insurance.

‚ÄúAbsent any changes on the congressional level, you‚Äôre going to see an increase in uncompensated care especially,‚Äù Washington said.

‚ÄúThose hospitals will still provision the care, but they would do so at great cost, so we‚Äôre trying to bolster on the state side, providing some resources to them to do just that,‚Äù he added.

The state is facing a $10.3 billion reduction in federal funding overall, per the budget office, with Hochul still retaining the option of raising taxes should Washington continue to further turn the screws on blue states like New York.

The executive budget is not expected to contribute new cash into the state‚Äôs $14.6 billion reserve funds even after Hochul raided them for $7 billion last year to pay off unemployment insurance debt owed to the federal government.

Hochul will lay out her executive proposal in a closely-watched address Tuesday morning, kicking off weeks of negotiating ‚Äì largely behind closed doors ‚Äì with the state legislature.

The state‚Äôs fiscal year turns over on April 1, though Hochul has purposely blown past that deadline in recent years as a negotiating tactic with the lawmakers, who do not receive pay while the spending plan is late.

Last year‚Äôs budget was finalized on May 8.

It‚Äôs unclear how much Hochul will be willing to play hard ball this year ahead of her re-election, where she is facing a Democratic Party primary challenge from her estranged Lt. Gov. Antonio Delgado.

She‚Äôs already choosing to dodge a potential knock-down-drag-out fight over changing the state‚Äôs controversial Raise the Age law, which restricts 16- and 17-year-olds from being tried as adults for non-felonies.

Many moderates and conservatives, along with NYPD Commissioner Jessica Tisch, argue the law led to a surge in violent crimes committed by and against teens in recent years.

Far-left Democrats and criminal justice groups, however, have preemptively dug their heels in over the last few months, sending a message to Hochul that she would potentially face immense political blowback if she took on that fight this year.

Hochul‚Äôs office told Spectrum News late last week she‚Äôd ultimately opt to avoid the fight altogether.
item.author: Vaughn Golden, Matt Troutman

item.description:
Activists on Big Apple college campuses are among those in the US who are peddling propaganda directly from Hamas that ‚Äúencourage[s] acts of violence against Jews,‚Äù a terrifying new study has found.

‚ÄúProtestors and activists are not merely praising the activity of terror groups; they are actively sharing their official propaganda, disseminating communiqu√©s, videos, and other materials directly onto mainstream platforms,‚Äù wrote the Anti-Defamation League Center on Extremism in its study titled, ‚ÄúDigital Couriers: How U.S. Anti-Israel Activists Amplify Terror Propaganda on Mainstream Platforms.‚Äù

The distribution of such hate on Telegram and other social-media platforms, including X and Instagram, since the Palestinian terror group Hamas‚Äô Oct. 7, 2023, attacks on Israel ‚Äúshows the increased normalization of rhetoric and messaging from terror organizations that overtly encourage acts of violence against Israel and Jewish people,‚Äù the report said.

‚ÄúThis shared material, which openly praises violent actions and actors, comes at a time of heightened danger for Jews worldwide with increased incidents of deadly antisemitic attacks,‚Äù researchers said.

‚ÄúAmerican Jews specifically have been navigating an unprecedentedly high threat landscape, marked by record levels of antisemitic incidents across the U.S.‚Äù

The terrorists‚Äô propaganda is picked up from the official channels and platforms of the deadly hate groups and translated into English and distributed by other pro-Hamas intermediary channels, the study said.

Resistance News Network ‚Äî a radical antisemitic, anti-Zionist, English-language Telegram channel with more than 150,000 subscribers and which promotes violence against Israel ‚Äî is one of the popular pass-along accounts.

Here are some examples involving the promotion of terroristic hate, according to the study:

  • The Bronx Anti-War Coalition disseminated propaganda directly from Hamas in March 2025. It reposted a Hamas poster and a caption added by antisemitic rapper Jonathan Azaziah on Global Resistance News saying, ‚ÄúThe day Israel is wiped off the face of the planet, we will sing, cheer, rejoice and dance the night away.‚Äù Azaziah added the hashtags #LongLiveTheFlood and #WeAreAllHamas. The caption appeared in full in the Bronx Anti-War re-post.
  • The Bronx Anti-War Coalition also reshared a violent post originally published by Hamas‚Äô military in support of a Houthi missile attack at Israel‚Äôs Ben Gurion Airport, which injured several people.
  • Anti-Israel activists have disseminated terror materials in person. As reported by The Post in March, protesters at Barnard College in Manhattan distributed a document in English written and circulated by Hamas‚Äô ‚Äúmedia office‚Äù explicitly justifying its Oct. 7 attack.
  • In July 2024, CUNY‚Äôs John Jay College‚Äôs Students for Justice in Palestine chapter ‚Äî which has nearly 1,000 followers ‚Äî shared a post on Instagram with a graphic from Hamas‚Äô Al Qassam Brigades and a message in Arabic translating to, ‚ÄúWe are coming like thunder, making a time of glory.‚Äù
  • University of Illinois Students for Palestine chapter shared a video on Instagram that showed what appeared to be a Hamas terrorist filming himself from inside the home of an Israeli family during the Oct. 7 attack. The caption read, ‚ÄúUnder the feet of the Mujahideen [those engaging in jihad], on this day,‚Äù apparently translating the terrorist‚Äôs remarks.
  • On Oct. 7, 2024, the SJP at the University of California at Davis shared a quote from now-deceased Hamas reo Abu Obaida on its Instagram account hailing the attack on Israel the year before. ‚ÄúA year has passed since the most successful and professional commando operation of the modern era,‚Äù the message said.

In order to disrupt the terror propaganda pipeline, ADL said social-media companies must rigorously enforce their existing policies, which often prohibit the sharing of content from federal terror organizations.

It also urged Congress to pass the Stopping Terrorists Online Presence and Holding Accountable Tech Entities Act, which would push companies to enforce their own policies to disrupt terrorist content on their platforms.

In addition, the watchdog group called on college officials to enforce campus rules for registered student organizations and faculty groups and clearly spell out when conduct, including distributing terror propaganda, violates campus policies and or state and federal law.

‚ÄúMore broadly, it is incumbent upon the general public to engage in due diligence when consuming and sharing content online and associating with activist groups and individuals,‚Äù the ADL said.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.description:
City drivers were slapped with a record number of tickets last year for illegally using traffic cones to score coveted parking spots ‚Äî but even their critics say the scofflaws deserve some sympathy.

The Sanitation Department dished out 533 traffic-cone-obstruction violations in 2025 after an equally record-setting 7,208 complaints were made about them to 311, according to a Post analysis of city data.

Last year‚Äôs more than 530 cone-related summonses ‚Äî issued mainly in Queens ‚Äî represented a nearly 6% increase from 2024, when 470 were doled out, an almost 100% jump from the 287 in 2023 and about a 900% hike from the 60 in 2022.

The parking issue became so heated last year that a mother and daughter attacked a college student over a parking spot ‚Äúreserved‚Äù by a neighbor with a garbage can in the Ridgewood section ‚Äî an assault caught on viral video.

‚ÄúPeople will park anywhere,‚Äù griped Rob Ennis, a 51-year-old resident of Glendale, Queens.

‚ÄúThe people next to me, they put out orange cones in places they shouldn‚Äôt. I had to fight with [other drivers] about it because they were taking up legal spots.‚Äù

A 42-year-old Ridgewood resident named JM said he‚Äôs heard of handicap walkers being used to reserve local spots ‚Äî and has considered putting out cones himself.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen [cones] about four times in different places, and I take them and move them,‚Äù he said.

Still, ‚Äúit‚Äôs usually an hour to find a parking spot,‚Äù JM said.

‚ÄúSometimes I have no choice and have to leave it in front of a fire hydrant,‚Äù he said of his car. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve lived here 30 years, and in the past 10 years, it‚Äôs become overcrowded.‚Äù

Queens represented more than 70% of the city‚Äôs traffic-cone violations issued in 2025, with 380 summonses handed out there. Out of 1,376 summonses issued across the Big Apple since 2020, 1,000 were given out in Queens, data show.

Queens Councilwoman Joann Ariola has blamed lax enforcement and limited space ‚Äî with spots gobbled by bike lanes and parking rules ‚Äî on the increase in illegal parking.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been happening for years,‚Äù said a 21-year-old Queens driver, Alex, of the cone-saving scofflaws.

But he said he‚Äôs sympathetic to the law violators.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so hard to park around here,‚Äù he said, ‚ÄúI understand people using cones to save parking spots.‚Äù

Local plumber Flori Kasa, 33, said she just takes matters into her own hands.

‚ÄúI move them, that‚Äôs it,‚Äù Kasa said while parking a car on Forest Avenue in Ridgewood.

‚ÄúNobody gets to take a spot with cones. I pay taxes. I don‚Äôt blame people for putting out cones, but it‚Äôs hard for me to park,‚Äù Kasa said.

The Queens resident recalled one confrontation she had with a woman standing in a parking spot to reserve it.

‚ÄúShe said she was saving it. I said, ‚ÄòNo, you‚Äôre not, I‚Äôm going to park there.‚Äô I wouldn‚Äôt move, she wouldn‚Äôt move. I stayed there one hour ‚Äî [and] I got the spot.‚Äù

Sanitation reps told The Post that traffic cones placed on the sidewalk or street are considered an illegal obstruction and therefore warrant administrative summonses with fines of up to $200 for repeat offenders.

But while more than 25,000 cone-related complaints have been made to 311 since 2020, violations were issued just over 5% of the time, The Post‚Äôs analysis found.

‚ÄúIn order for us to issue a summons for this, the owner of the cones has to acknowledge that the cones are theirs,‚Äù a Sanitation Department rep said.¬†

‚ÄúWe do investigate complaints for this by visiting the home and speaking with the homeowner. If they claim ownership of the cones, we will issue a summons for street obstruction. ‚Ä¶ If they do not claim the cones as their own, we will simply take them away.‚Äù
item.author: Nicole Rosenthal, Jennifer Bain

item.description:
A ‚Äúsevere‚Äù geomagnetic storm could bring a kaleidoscopic array of colors to night skies across the US on Monday ‚Äî including parts of New York and New Jersey, according to forecasters.

An expulsion of plasma and magnetic fields from the sun‚Äôs outermost layer, known as a coronal mass ejection, hurled toward Earth on Sunday after a massive X1.9-class solar flare ‚Äî reaching our planet by Monday afternoon, according to a¬†forecast¬†by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration‚Äôs Space Weather Prediction Center.

The storm conditions could make the northern lights visible from New York to Washington state, and as far south as Alabama by Monday night, forecasters said.

The stunning aurora borealis will be able to be viewed just outside New York City, but is more likely to be visible farther from the city lights in upstate New York. Parts of New Jersey could also see a dazzling display.

The best time to view the light show in the US is between 10 p.m. and 4 a.m., and prospective viewers should head to the darkest possible location with clear skies for the highest chances of seeing it.

The shock wave from the¬†CME¬†struck Earth at 2:38 p.m. and quickly reached a severe (G4) category geomagnetic storm after its impact, according to NOAA.

G4 storms are capable of disrupting power systems and satellite operations worldwide, forecasters warn.

The northern lights were visible in New York City, including parts of Queens, Mineola, and East Hampton, as recently as November, according to Pix11.
item.author: Zoe Hussain

item.description:
The largest nurses strike in Big Apple history stretched into a second week Monday with no end in sight ‚Äìas some medical workers even protested outside hospital execs‚Äô homes.

New York State Nurses Association members went to the home of Montefiore CEO Philip Ozuah on Sunday with signs that read, ‚ÄúHospital execs literally make us sick‚Äù as they decried their working conditions.

Striking workers also picketed outside the homes of executives with Mount Sinai and NewYork-Presbyterian, chanting, ‚ÄúNo justice, no peace ‚Äì until we get a fair contract,‚Äù according to the NYSNA.

‚ÄúSince wealthy hospital CEOs won‚Äôt meet nurses at the bargaining table, striking nurses took their message from the picket lines directly to the hospital CEOs where they live,‚Äù NYSNA President Nancy Hagans said in a statement Sunday.

Greater New York Hospital Association President Kenneth Raske slammed the union‚Äôs tactics in a statement Monday night.

‚ÄúIntimidation is not an attribute you would normally associate with caregivers,‚Äù he said.

More than 15,000 nurses have been on strike against the major hospitals in the city since last Monday, with some saying they are ready for the long haul.

‚ÄúHow long are we willing to fight for? Until this hospital is willing to come to the table and have a fair conversation about this,‚Äù said ICU¬†nurse Josh Wilson, 45, outside NY-Presbyterian/Columbia University Medical Center on Monday.

‚ÄúI personally am willing to fight till the very end,‚Äù he said.

The hospitals and nurses are at odds over various issues, including pay, staffing levels and health-insurance benefits.

About 1,000 nurses demonstrated outside NY-Presbyterian medical facilities in the frigid temperatures with hand and foot warmers laid out on a table Monday.

Cindy Collier, a 61-year-old nurse with Milstein Hospital in the system, said healthcare workers are stretched too thin and patients are quick to blame them.

‚ÄúWe stand strong, and we are out here for as long as it takes, because it‚Äôs not fair for patients to go back into the working conditions we are in,‚Äù said the 36-year nurse.

Another Milstein nurse, Bobby Ancog, 58, said he thinks hospital executives are attempting to wait out the striking staff ‚Äúbecause they know we have bills to pay.

‚ÄúI think I can manage, but I don‚Äôt know about the others,‚Äù he said.

Hospital leaders didn‚Äôt seem optimistic the strike was close to over.

Mount Sinai CEO Brendan Carr said in an email to staff Monday, ‚ÄúA near-term path to an agreement is very unlikely.

‚ÄúAs I indicated when I last wrote to you, our negotiating teams met with NYSNA‚Äôs negotiating teams on Friday. After little progress was made at either table, the mediators told the parties to break,‚Äù he wrote, adding no additional meetings are scheduled for now.

Montefiore said Monday that ‚Äúprogress overall will not be possible‚Äù with the nurses until ‚Äúthey can back away from their reckless and dangerous $3.6 billion demands.

‚ÄúIn the meantime, we continue to provide the world-class care our communities deserve,‚Äù a hospital rep said.

NY-Presbyterian defended the pay and benefits it was offering nurses while saying it was committed to safe staffing.

‚ÄúNYSNA‚Äôs demands remain unrealistic,‚Äù a hospital spokesperson said, noting the two sides need to schedule another bargaining session with a mediator.

Nurses met with NY-Presbyterian and Mount Sinai officials late last week, and were at the bargaining table with Montefiore management Sunday evening, according to the nurses‚Äô union.

‚ÄúI really didn‚Äôt think we were going to be out here this long, but we are prepared,‚Äù said Morgan Stanley Children‚Äôs¬†Hospital pediatric ER nurse Vanessa Moreira, 35.
item.author: Steven Vago, Carl Campanile, David Propper

item.title: MamdaniÂ§çÊ¥ª‰∫Ü83‰∏™Âçï‰ΩçÁöÑÂâçÂõöÁäØ‰ΩèÊàøÈ°πÁõÆÔºå Eric AdamsËØïÂõæÈòªÊ≠¢Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏Ç
item.description:
Zoh‚Äôs bringing inmates back home.

Mayor Zohran Mamdani on Monday revived the ‚ÄúJust Home‚Äù supportive housing project for ex-inmates in the Bronx that his predecessor Eric Adams tried to nix.

The move will bring more than 80 new apartments to Jacobi Medical Center for formerly incarcerated seniors who have complex medical needs beyond the capabilities of homeless shelters.

Mamdani said he found it fitting to announce the project on Martin Luther King Jr. Day.

‚ÄúWe are not simply creating 83 new apartments and supporting those who are struggling, we are advancing the cause of justice,‚Äù he said during a news conference at Jacobi, flanked by city officials, advocates and former inmates.

‚ÄúThis is a project which will provide a rent-stabilized lease to every single tenant, and it will prove that our commitment to homeless New Yorkers, and those who need supportive housing, is anything but abstract. It is tangible and it is actionable.‚Äù

Just Homes‚Äô future had been plunged into uncertainty last year when Adams, who previously supported the project, told City Council members he planned to change its location.

A letter from Adams‚Äô First Deputy Mayor Randy Mastro pointed to opposition in the local community, including now-former city Councilwoman Kristy Marmorato (R-Bronx), as the reason for the about-face.

Mastro instead pushed to move the project to Brooklyn.

City Council members blasted Adams‚Äô rug pull as a tactic to score political points for his then-active, if clearly doomed, re-election campaign.

They voted to approve a 99-year sublease for the project, keeping it alive.

Mamdani‚Äôs maneuver showed his City Hall won‚Äôt try to hinder the project, unlike his predecessor.

Mitchell Katz, the president and CEO of Health + Hospitals, seemed to slyly shade Adams as he stood beside Mamdani.

‚ÄúWow, what a great mayor we have and what an amazing commitment,‚Äù he said, drawing laughs.
item.author: Ella Morrison, Matt Troutman

item.description:
A federal judge has lifted President Trump‚Äôs stop-work order on a massive offshore wind project on Long Island‚Äôs South Shore ‚Äî allowing construction to restart immediately.¬†

The state-backed Empire Wind project, a $6 billion offshore wind development located roughly 14 miles off the coast of Jones Beach, can fully resume construction after being illegally halted by the Trump administration in December, judge Carl Nichols ruled Thursday.¬†

The Trump administration cited vague national security concerns when it brought the project to a screeching halt in December.

The developer Equinor, a Norwegian energy company hired by Albany to install the wind farm along the region‚Äôs coast, said the reason behind the stop-work order was never fully explained to them ‚Äî sparking a lawsuit against the US Department of Interior.¬†

‚Äú[The Empire Wind project was] stopped under the bogus pretense of national security,‚Äù Gov. Kathy Hochul said in a statement.¬†

‚ÄúThe work was done, the platforms were built, thousands of workers from Long Island to New York City and beyond have been working through all kinds of weather to do something that is critically important for our energy future and has been contemplated as part of our grid ‚Äî [and] the Trump administration shut it down.‚Äù¬†

The project, which was more than 60% complete when it was suspended, was at risk of missing critical construction deadlines that could have sunk the entire project, according to court filings.

Thursday‚Äôs preliminary injunction allows Equinor to immediately restart offshore construction and continue work on the 810-megawatt wind farm, which is expected to begin delivering power to over 500,000 people across parts of New York City later this year.¬†

Equinor has already invested roughly $4 billion into the project and plans to spend another $2 billion to complete it, court papers said. ¬†

‚ÄúEmpire Wind will now focus on safely restarting construction activities that were halted during the suspension period. In addition, the project will continue to engage with the U.S. government to ensure the safe, secure and responsible execution of its operations,‚Äù David Schoetz, a spokesperson for Equinor, said in a statement.¬†

Nassau County Executive Bruce Blakeman, a Republican who governs the region along the project‚Äôs coastline, did not respond to a request for comment ‚Äî but has repeatedly outspoken against the project.¬†

‚ÄúThe residents of Nassau County do not want offshore wind turbines,‚Äù Blakeman, who is running for governor, told a Long Island Association breakfast earlier this month.¬†

Meanwhile, other state offshore wind projects such as Sunrise Wind along the shores in Suffolk County ‚Äî which Republican County Executive Ed Romaine has repeatedly made clear he was in favor of ‚Äî remain stalled under separate federal orders.

Sunrise Wind, which is slated to deliver nearly 1,000 megawatts of power to the Long Island grid by 2028, is still seeking court approval to resume work.
item.author: Brandon Cruz

item.title: 35Â≤ÅÁöÑÈôåÁîü‰∫∫Âú®2026Âπ¥ÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∫åÊ¨°ÈöèÊú∫Âú∞ÈìÅÊé®ÈÄÅ‰∏≠Â∞ÜÁî∑Â≠êÊé®Âà∞Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÁÅ´ËΩ¶ËΩ®ÈÅì‰∏äÔºöË≠¶ÂØüÔºåÊ∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫ê
item.description:
A stranger pushed a 35-year-old man onto Brooklyn train tracks in an unprovoked burst of violence over the weekend ‚Äì marking the second random subway shove of the year, cops and sources said.¬†

The victim was standing on the southbound R train platform at 36th Street in Sunset Park around 4:55 a.m. Sunday, when the wacko walked up and knocked him onto the roadbed without saying a word, according to authorities and sources.

The attacker bolted and had not been caught as of Monday afternoon, police said.¬†

Luckily, no trains appeared to be approaching the station at the time and the victim was helped back onto the platform by responding officers, the sources said.¬†

The victim was taken to NYU Langone Hospital-Brooklyn, where he‚Äôs listed in stable condition, police said.

The suspect, shown near the turnstile area in photos released by the NYPD Monday afternoon, has dark curly hair and a short beard, and was last seen wearing a black and gray jacket with khakis.¬†

The scary incident is the second to happen less than a month into 2026.

The new year kicked off with its first unprovoked subway shoving incident on day one. In that incident, an apparently intoxicated medical student hailing from Russia allegedly shoved a 72-year-old man into a moving Bronx train around 3:30 a.m. New Year‚Äôs Day, cops and sources said.

The victim was knocked unconscious during that attack, but was ultimately hospitalized in stable condition, according to cops and prosecutors.

Suspect Anton Aleshin, 29, was arrested and charged with attempted murder and has since been ordered held without bail.¬†

Officials had touted a promising end of 2025 in the transit system, with a 4% drop in major subway crime compared to 2024. They highlighted a 12.5% decline in robberies ‚Äî marking an all-time low ‚Äî and a 62.5% drop in shootings.

Anyone with information that could lead to an arrest in the latest subway shove is asked to call the NYPD‚Äôs Crime Stoppers Hotline at 1-800-577-TIPS (8477) or for Spanish, 1-888-57-PISTA (74782).

The public can also submit their tips by logging onto the Crimestoppers website at https://crimestoppers.nypdonline.org/, or on X @NYPDTips.
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.title: LIÂ≠¶Ê†°Ëë£‰∫ã‰ºöËÄÅÊùøÂèëËµ∑‰∫ÜÊãØÊïëÈÖãÈïøÈòüÁöÑÊñó‰∫âÔºåÂπ∂‰∫âÂèñ‰∫ÜÁâπÊúóÊôÆÁöÑÂ∏ÆÂä©Ôºå‰ªñ‰ª¨ÁöÑÁõÆÂÖâÊäïÂêë‰∫ÜÂ∑ûÂèÇËÆÆÈô¢
item.description:
She‚Äôs looking to make Albany great again.

The relentless Long Island school board boss fighting to keep her district‚Äôs ‚ÄúChiefs‚Äù team name is ‚Äúgiving strong consideration‚Äù to a state Senate run, The Post has learned.

‚ÄúI believe our district deserves leadership that puts students, families, and taxpayers first,‚Äù Massapequa Board of Education President Kerry Wachter, 53, said.

The President Trump-backer is eyeing the District 8 seat, which spans Nassau County‚Äôs Massapequa to the Patchogue border in Suffolk, after incumbent Republican Alexis Weik recently announced she will not seek reelection.

Should the Republican decide to take on liberal Albany, her campaign would center on ‚Äúimproving schools, supporting families, and ensuring that parents have a voice in their children‚Äôs education,‚Äù she told The Post.

‚ÄúAt this time, I am listening to community members and evaluating whether a campaign would allow me to continue serving in a way that makes the greatest impact,‚Äù added Wachter, a mom of three.

State assemblymen Michael Durso, whose office is in Wachter‚Äôs home hamlet of Massapequa, and Jarett Gandolfo, who‚Äôs headquartered in Bayport, are among the growing list of names mulling a move for the seat, a source told The Post.

No candidates have yet to officially enter the race.

Wachter, who fashions herself as anti-woke, sparked national headlines last year, aggressively fighting Albany¬†in court to keep the Massapequa Chiefs logo after a statewide 2023 Board of Regents ban.

Those who‚Äôve worked or interacted with Wachter since she joined the school board in 2019 gave top marks to the scout mom and Sunday school instructor who is married to an NYPD inspector.

‚ÄúOne of the things that she has been so adamant about is local control for the school districts,‚Äù said former Massapequa school board member Gary Baldinger, who played in the NFL for several seasons.

‚ÄúAs a town, we want to be able to keep our local control,‚Äù added Baldinger, who credited Wachter‚Äôs ability to ‚Äúreach across the aisle‚Äù and called her ‚Äúa tireless worker for Massapequa.‚Äù

Rose Stein, a local parent of three, echoed the sentiment.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs admirable. She motivates other people to do things. She‚Äôs a champion for the kids of this community,‚Äù Stein said.

‚ÄúI just think that this would be the perfect fit for her,‚Äù the mom added of Wachter‚Äôs potential run.

Chief concern

The board president showed moxie and political chops after a federal judge initially ruled against Massapequa keeping the Chiefs‚Äô name in early spring.

It was a time when several other Long Island schools with similar Native American imagery either dropped litigation or were priced out of court battles, despite community support.

‚ÄúThere were many people who pleaded with the board, saying, ‚ÄòPlease don‚Äôt give up this fight,'‚Äù Stein added.

‚ÄúShe listens to the community ‚Ä¶ she‚Äôs not going to give up.‚Äù

Instead, Wachter pulled out all the stops and sent an SOS to the White House in April, pleading for Trump to intervene ‚Äî which he did days later.

‚ÄúI agree with the people in Massapequa, Long Island, who are fighting furiously to keep the Massapequa Chiefs logo on their Teams and School,‚Äù Trump¬†posted on Truth Social.¬†

‚ÄúLONG LIVE THE MASSAPEQUA CHIEFS!‚Äù he added, posing with a Massapequa sweatshirt in the Oval Office alongside Brian Kilmeade shortly after.

That slogan even appeared on shirts¬†sold at a ‚ÄúSave the Chiefs‚Äù fundraiser¬†in June following¬†Secretary of Education Linda McMahon‚Äôs tour of Massapequa High School.

McMahon announced a probe into New York‚Äôs ban on indigenous team names inside the Chiefs‚Äô gym alongside Wachter, a¬†‚Äútop priority‚Äù fight¬†that remains tied up in litigation.

‚ÄúA lot of things fell in place that allowed that to happen, but being the [board] president, she made those things happen, said Baldinger.

‚ÄúI give her all the credit.‚Äù

Wachter also joined fellow educators and local parents in launching a December lawsuit against state Attorney General Letitia James, for allegedly intimidating students and community members who voiced concerns about trans athletes performing in youth sports.

If she jumps into the November race, Wachter also plans to focus on ‚Äúimproving education, restoring public safety, lowering taxes, and advancing responsible policies that make New York more affordable for families.‚Äù
item.author: Alex Mitchell

item.description:
Two men died after falling through the ice of an upstate New York lake during an ice fishing trip ‚Äî with the only survivor a 6-year-old boy who miraculously walked home, authorities said Monday.

Bryan LaPlante, 33, of Newton Falls, and 48-year-old Michael Booth, of Oswegatchie, and the youngster were out fishing on Chaumont Pond in St. Lawrence County on Sunday when their snowmobile broke through the ice, state police said in a press release.

Unaware of the tragedy, a relative, Patrick LaPlante, 51, grew worried and went out looking for the trio and spotted Bryan LaPlante in the icy water, according to the troopers.

Police did not reveal what the relationship was between the two men.

However, they said the older man crawled toward Bryan LaPlante as he struggled in the water ‚Äî only to fall through the ice himself, the press release said.

He was able to climb out of the water but lost sight of the two missing men.

Police, who responded to the scene around 7:40 p.m. said Patrick LaPlante had returned home to warm up ‚Äî when the 6-year-old boy suddenly showed up at the home drenched and freezing ‚Äî but alive ‚Äî after walking from the scene of the frigid and deadly mishap by himself.

Both were taken to Clinton-Fine Hospital and treated for hypothermia.

Meanwhile, state police rushed to the pond and located Bryan LaPlante and Booth, who were unresponsive and still in the water, plucking the two out and performing CPR.

Both were taken to Gouverneur Hospital, where they were pronounced dead.
item.author: Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.description:
Roughly 10,000 gallons of raw sewage unloaded into the Peconic River during a construction mishap at a Long Island apartment complex ‚Äî but local officials claim there‚Äôs no need for a cleanup.

A broken sewer pipe at a Riverhead construction site spilled dirty waste into the Peconic River for over 45 straight minutes last Wednesday, prompting the Suffolk County Department of Health to issue a safety advisory to stay out of the water at Grangebel Park.

But despite the warning, Riverhead Sewer District Superintendent Tim Allen told the town board Thursday night that any type of cleanup was unnecessary ‚Äî claiming toxins had already seeped into the ground.¬†

‚ÄúThere was no cleanup because it saturated into the ground,‚Äù Allen said.

The superintendent told the board that he didn‚Äôt see ‚Äúanything‚Äù but ‚Äúclean groundwater‚Äù flowing into the river when he checked the filtration box setup to collect runoff at the construction site. ‚ÄúNo smell, no odor,‚Äù Allen said.

The broken pipe was replaced within an hour, and officials from the Suffolk Health Department and the state Department of Environmental Conservation later took samples from the river, with results expected to be released this week, Allen said.¬†

Environmental activists argued that it‚Äôs far too early to dismiss the threat and warned that even short-term sewage discharges can have lingering effects in slow-moving waterways like the Peconic ‚Äî especially during colder months when bacteria can persist longer.

‚Äú[The government] really needs to keep an eye on this, they can‚Äôt just say no harm, no foul ‚Äî that amount of raw sewage can certainly cause major problems,‚Äù John Di Leonardo, the president of Humane Long Island, told The Post.¬†

The raw sewage leak could cause a slew of issues, including algae blooms, botulism ‚Äî a rare illness caused by a nerve toxin ‚Äî and could even cause harm all the way up the whole food chain, according to Di Leonardo.¬†

But until the state and county‚Äôs reporting on the river‚Äôs water samples comes back, there is no way of knowing for sure what the impacts will be, he said.¬†

‚ÄúLast year‚Äôs PSEG oil spill, which the company and DEC called ‚Äònonhazardous,‚Äô we recovered numerous dead animals from that spill despite stakeholders downplaying its effects ‚Äî so it‚Äôs always wise to approach comments downplaying spills with healthy skepticism,‚Äù he added.

Suffolk officials did not say how long the advisory would remain in effect or whether additional testing would be conducted.

Riverhead officials also did not disclose whether any action would be taken against the contractor responsible for the sewer line break, or if the developer could face penalties.
item.author: Brandon Cruz

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Ê∞ë‰∏ªÂÖöÂú®‰ºóËÆÆÈô¢ÂàùÈÄâ‰∏≠ÊãíÁªùÂú®Â∞¥Â∞¨ÁöÑ‰∫§ÊµÅ‰∏≠ÂõûÁ≠îMamdaniÁöÑÊîØÊåÅ‚ÄîÂÖ∂‰∏≠‰∏Ä‰∫∫ÁîöËá≥ÈöêËóè‰∫ÜÂ•πÁöÑËÑ∏
item.description:
Welp, this is awkward.

Five Democrats running in a suburban congressional primary refused to say if they‚Äôd accept Mayor Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs endorsement ‚Äì with one candidate covering her face when asked about a potential nod.

Video shows the five hopefuls, who are looking to take on two-term Republican Rep. Mike Lawler for a Hudson Valley seat in the House of Representatives, confronted about whether they‚Äôd want the endorsement of the democratic socialist mayor of the Big Apple.

The crew of Dems were approached by a Republican tracker outside a Jan. 13 forum hosted by the left-wing activist group Indivisible.

‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt talked to [Mamdani,‚Äù candidate John Cappello said, according to the video. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt anticipate that he‚Äôs going to give me a call.

Fellow Democrats Peter Chatzky, John Sullivan and Mike Sacks all dodged the question ‚Äî and candidate Effie Phillips-Staley hid her face with both hands when asked about Mamdani.

GOP strategists are trying to turn Mamdani into a campaign issue in state races outside of the five boroughs, with the idea that his left-wing agenda and views will turn off suburban and upstate voters this fall.

‚ÄúMamdani will be a liability for Democrats in November. He will be in a lot of Republican ads and mailers,‚Äù Republican pollster John McLaughlin said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking forward to it.‚Äù

Last fall, the Nassau County GOP on Long Island spent $2 million on mail and ads that featured Mamdani with Democratic candidates. Republicans romped in those local races.

Republican National Committee chairman Joe Gruters said Mamdani and fellow Democratic Socialists of America member Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez are the ‚Äúnew face‚Äù of the Democratic Party and the further they push Dems left in primaries helps Republicans in the general election.

‚ÄúThat helps all of our candidates on the Republican side because we are the party of reasonableness and common sense. I think that the other side has lost touch on reality,‚Äù he said on 77 WABC radio‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Cats Roundtable‚Äù Sunday.

Still, some independent analysts doubt that the Republicans will be able to maintain control of the House in the midterm elections this fall.

The non-partisan Cook Political Report moved 18 House races nationwide more toward Democrats, including a few races in New York.

Cook changed the rating last week for Lawler‚Äôs seat from ‚Äúlean Republican‚Äù to ‚Äútossup.‚Äù New York‚Äôs 17th Congressional District includes suburbs north of the city, with a northern swath of Westchester County as well as Rockland County and parts of Putnam and Dutchess counties.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÁñØÂ≠êÂºÄÊû™ÊâìÊ≠ªÂÖ¨Ë∑ØÊÑ§ÊÄíÂèëËÑæÊ∞îÁöÑÁî∑Â≠êÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÊ≠•Ë°åÈÄÉË∑ëÔºöË≠¶ÂØü
item.description:
A Bronx brute shot a man during a crazed road rage tantrum, then ran off and left the victim clinging to life, cops and sources said on Monday.

Frankie Poventud, 41, allegedly opened fire and hit a 36-year-old man during a clash at Concourse Village and East 156th Street on Friday just before 4 p.m., according to the sources and authorities.

It wasn‚Äôt clear if Poventud had been in a vehicle or if the victim had been a driver or passenger.

The victim ‚Äì who did not know Poventud ‚Äì was taken by private means to Lincoln Medical Center, where he was listed in critical condition, cops said.¬†

Poventud, of Mount Hope, allegedly fled on foot, before turning himself in at the 44th Precinct stationhouse nearly two days later on Sunday evening, police said.¬†

In addition to the attempted murder rap, Poventud was also charged with assault, reckless endangerment and criminal possession of a weapon, authorities said.¬†

His arraignment was pending late Monday.

The shocking daytime gunfire came weeks after a deadly road rage-fueled shooting in the Bronx on New Year‚Äôs Day.¬†

Hard-working Uber driver Issa Mbolo-Isac, 55, was shot and killed at the intersection of Morris Avenue and the Cross Bronx Expressway just before 7 a.m. Jan. 1 ‚Äì marking the city‚Äôs first homicide of the year, cops said.¬†

Representatives from the New York State Federation of Taxi Drivers said at the time that Mbolo-Isac was callously shot during an argument over a fender-bender.¬†

The NYPD has named Ehinel Troncoso, 24, as a suspect, but he has not yet been caught.¬†
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.title: Âú®Êó∂Â∞öÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë°óÂå∫ÁàÜÂèëÂèåÈôÜÊ£ãÊàò‰∫âÔºåÁé©ÂÆ∂‰∫âÂ§∫ÊàêÊú¨
item.description:
A major split ignited a wild recent backgammon turf war in a trendy Big Apple neighborhood.

The dicey board battle pitting an insurgent group of players in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, against the city‚Äôs established club centered around the ancient game sprouted in July ‚Äî and took on a life of its own.

The rogue Greenpoint Backgammon Club began defiantly hosting regular weekly ‚Äúno snobs, no fees, no bulls‚Äìt‚Äù game nights after its members split from the much more polished NYC Backgammon Club, which includes a $10 pay-for-play rule.

‚ÄúWe just open a board, and whoever wants to play can play,‚Äù said one of the founding Greenpoint members to The Post, speaking on condition of anonymity because of the bad blood around the schism.

‚ÄúIt would be so insane for me to ask you for money to do that. Can you imagine?‚Äù

But Remington Davenport, a California transplant who made the NYC Backgammon Club so popular, she was able to ditch her sales job to run the club full-time, downplayed the ‚Äúbeef‚Äù ‚Äî and extended an olive branch to the insurgent group after The Post started asking around.

The gammon drama erupted over the summer when people showed up at the hip Scrappeland bar on Manhattan Avenue for an evening of play, only to find that the meet-up had been canceled without warning because of low turnout.

The bar was one of many sites where NYC Backgammon Club had been hosting weekly game nights. Players would pay $10 for unlimited play, a cost that doesn‚Äôt go toward any food or drink vouchers or board rentals. Players are even asked to bring their own boards.

Since the small group of wannabe players had already arrived that night with their boards in hand, they decided to still play ‚Äî without the $10 fee. They then continued their free weekly game nights locally outside of the structured club because they all live in the trendy nabe.

But when Davenport caught wind of the unsanctioned chapter, which had grown to 20 players, she tried to get it shut down, a player claimed.

‚ÄúShe wanted to control it. She wanted to approve any messaging before it went out,‚Äù the player said.

Davenport allegedly sent a series of messages telling the players they weren‚Äôt allowed to form a spinoff on her ‚Äúterritory‚Äù without paying her, effectively trying to absorb the Greenpoint Backgammon Club into her ‚Äúambassador‚Äù program, members of the offshoot said.

‚ÄúAmbassadors‚Äù run smaller recurring game nights on behalf of NYC Backgammon Club with the same $10 admission, although they are not paid for hosting, an ambassador told The Post.

‚ÄúThe whole moral of the story is: It‚Äôs not like anyone had t-shirts or hats or club signs,‚Äù said a Greenpoint Backgammon member of their group‚Äôs spin-off. ‚ÄúNo one ever swore loyalty to one group or another.

‚ÄúIt was just people who were looking to organize and play.‚Äù

But Davenport said she has since ‚Äúsquashed the beef‚Äù between the warring groups ‚Äî but only after she was ripped on¬†social media¬†over her ‚Äúbogus business model.‚Äù

She said she made a gesture of peace toward the Greenpoint group through Instagram‚Äôs direct messaging more than a week ago.

‚ÄúI told them, ‚ÄòI fully support you guys. I will send people to your club.‚Äô No biggie. I don‚Äôt want any trouble or drama,‚Äù Davenport said.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre doing their own thing, and that‚Äôs fine.‚Äù

She admitted there had been friction between the two groups, but that from her end, it was fueled by her own personal life hardships and that she was only ‚Äúmad for a day.‚Äù

The backgammon titan previously told The Post the mission for the club was to foster community in real life and offline.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre just looking for new opportunities to have an experience and to meet friends, so that‚Äôs been super successful,‚Äù Davenport said, adding that numerous couples have met and even gotten married after meeting at her club.

Davenport said she started NYC Backgammon shortly after moving to the Big Apple in April 2023, upon which she quickly realized the majority of public games were limited to ‚Äúvery old white men.‚Äù

Since then, Davenport has helped to launch ‚ÄúGirls who Gammon‚Äù and ‚ÄúGays who Gammon,‚Äù clubs that aim to create safe spaces for minorities not typically included in backgammon games, she said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs truly a community,‚Äù Davenport said.

‚ÄúBackgammon is still so niche, so people are just looking to connect.‚Äù
item.author: Katherine Donlevy

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇËÆ°ÂàíÁªùÂØÜÁöÑÂú∞‰∏ãÂú∞ÂõæÔºåËØ¶ÁªÜËØ¥ÊòéÁÆ°ÈÅìÔºåÁîµÂä®‚ÄîÂ∏åÊúõÂÆÉÂèØ‰ª•ÊåΩÊïëÁîüÂëΩÔºåÊåΩÊïëÈáëÈí±
item.description:
The creation of an exclusive underground map of the Big Apple is reportedly in the works, which officials claim could curb millions in overruns on construction projects and also save lives.

The centralized, high-tech digital blueprint would help workers navigate the city‚Äôs thorny subsurface terrain, including a wild maze of water and gas pipes and electrical lines, top city officials told Gothamist Monday.

Crews that currently dig up different streets and sidewalks can deal with unexpected discoveries that stall projects and can lead to millions in added costs, argued Thomas Wynne, deputy commissioner for the city‚Äôs Design and Construction Department.

While the map is being trumpeted as critically important, only certain members of city government will be privy to it ‚Äî for a limited time, Steinberg told Gothamist.

With the new map, a city employee with the proper approvals would request information from different partners for a specific project that the map would then visualize in 3D, according to the report.

The data would disappear, however, when it‚Äôs no longer needed or clearance ends.

That‚Äôs because city officials are so afraid the map could end up in the hands of bad actors ‚Äî who could conceivably target underground infrastructure in some kind of attack.

‚ÄúSecurity concerns are not only legitimate, but inform the entire design of the project,‚Äù Steinberg told the publication.

‚ÄúWe have an elaborate project architecture because there‚Äôs so much paranoia around storing all this data in a static environment.‚Äù

The new plan could also boost response time for first responders during an emergency, according to the outlet.

‚ÄúOur own emergency response professionals describe scenarios where they‚Äôre layering paper maps on the hoods of cars at the site of an emergency,‚Äù said Dan Steinberg, who is the director of the Mayor‚Äôs Office of Operation, which is leading the map‚Äôs creation.

‚ÄúThat to me, encapsulates the problem. More can go wrong when you‚Äôre working in this archaic way.‚Äù

The effort to put together a wide-ranging map would require help from different private entities like Con Edison, Nation Grid and MTA ‚Äî and is being paid for with a $10 million federal grant, the outlet reported.

The map is expected to be unveiled at the start of 2028, according to Gothamist.

The Post has sought comment from city officials.
item.author: David Propper

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏Ç‰∏ö‰∏ªÈù¢‰∏¥Â¢ûÁ®éÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫MamdaniÁöÑÁßüÈáëÂÜªÁªìÊâøËØ∫ÂèØËÉΩ‰ºöÂØºËá¥‰ª∑Ê†ºÈ£ôÂçá
item.description:
There‚Äôs no freeze on soaring costs.

City homeowners and landlords are bracing for a hike in their property taxes, as Mayor Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs ‚Äúrent-freeze‚Äù promise can send prices soaring for residents who don‚Äôt live in rent-controlled apartments.

Building owners whose stock includes government-regulated apartments said that if the socialist mayor gets his wish of a ‚Äúrent freeze‚Äù for the rent-controlled units could make it harder to maintain their properties ‚Äî and could force them to hike rents for market-rate properties to make up the difference.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt have your cake and eat it, too. You can‚Äôt say you want to freeze the rent and then raise my property taxes,‚Äù said Humberto Lopes, CEO of HL Dynasty and the Gotham Housing Alliance, who owns 100 properties.

Lopes said a 20-story, rent-regulated apartment building he owns on 446 Senator St. in the Bay Ridge neighborhood would jump from $78,000 to $91,000 under updated assessment rolls that saw valuation on co-ops, condos, and apartment buildings by 6.2%.

Meanwhile, single-family houses or buildings with up to three units saw assessments go up 4.7%, which could also send property tax bills soaring.

‚ÄúYou want to freeze the rent? Freeze the property taxes or lower them. Right now, you‚Äôre increasing the expenses to my building.‚Äù

The city Department of Finance let the cat out of the bag about a pending property tax hike when it released preliminary assessment rolls for properties last week, covering the fiscal year July 1, 2026, through June 30, 2027. The rolls partially dictate forthcoming hikes.

Property taxes will rise to account for the surging market value of the city‚Äôs housing stock, not a hike in the tax rate.

DOF reported that:

  • For Class 1 properties covering one-to-three family homes, assessed values rose an average of 4.7%.
  • Staten Island homes had the greatest percentage increase in assessed value, up 5.1%.
  • Assessments jumped an average of 6.2% on Class 2 properties covering co-ops, condos and rental apartment buildings.
  • In Mamdani-loving Brooklyn, co-op and apartment buildings saw an 11.1% increase, the highest in the city.
  • For commercial properties, assessment increased by 5.8%.
  • Commercial properties in the Bronx saw the largest increase in assessed value, at 11%.
  • Assessed value for office buildings increased by 4.2%, and retail buildings saw a 5.9% increase.
  • Brooklyn had the largest increase in assessed value for retail buildings at 7.6%

‚ÄúThese higher assessments mean one thing: higher property tax bills,‚Äù said a spokesperson for Homeowners for an Affordable New York.

‚ÄúMayor Mamdani promised to make the city more affordable; yet under his watch, the city is quietly hiking taxes that property owners will inevitably pass on to tenants,‚Äù the spokesperson said. ‚ÄúRising assessments are an invisible rent hike for every tenant in New York, and ordinary homeowners are being squeezed, too.‚Äù

Meanwhile, small property owners filed a lawsuit last fall claiming New York State‚Äôs Rent Stabilization Law of 2019 makes it economically unfeasible to lease vacant apartments because of caps imposed on rents on units that are unoccupied.

There are about 1 million rent-stabilized units in the city whose rent is set by members of the Rent Guidelines Board appointed by the mayor.

Brothers Pashko and Tony Lulgjuraj said in the suit that the rent in one of the vacant units in their building is capped at $700, and they claimed they would lose money for years if they rented it out.

The case is just a microcosm. In 2024, the Census Bureau released data showing there are more than 26,000 ‚Äúzombie units‚Äù in the regulated stock‚Äì rent-controlled apartments that are vacant and off the market.

Lopes, the landlord, said owners of one-to three-family homes will also get squeezed.

He owns three three-family homes on Coffey Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn, and estimates the property taxes on these buildings could increase from the current $35,151 to about $38,000.

‚ÄúIn Red Hook. Is that crazy?‚Äù Lopes said.

The Mamdani administration pushed back on a possible property hike.

‚ÄúNo, the City has not increased property taxes [rates] since January 1st ‚Äî the last mayor to do so was [Mike] Bloomberg,‚Äù spokesperson Dore Pekec said Sunday.

‚ÄúThis annual preliminary report is simply an assessment of property values,‚Äù Pekec said. ‚ÄúThe mayor has made it clear he plans to advocate for reform to our broken property tax system.‚Äù

City Hall also noted the assessed value reflects new construction as well as economic growth and housing market changes, and is only one component used to calculate a property tax bill. There are annual assessment caps in place under the law that limit large increases.

Mamdani caused a stir during his successful mayoral campaign when he said he wanted to shift the tax burden from ‚Äúovertaxed‚Äù homeowners in the outer boroughs to ‚Äúmore expensive homes in richer and whiter neighborhoods.‚Äù

He also said he would seek a change in state law to stop treating co-ops and condos as if they were rental properties to smooth out the tax burden.

DOF sends a Notice of Property Value to owners, including information about market and assessed value, and other property information.

The NOPV gives property owners the opportunity to review their tentative assessments and file a challenge with the city Tax Commission, an independent city agency, before the assessment roll is finalized in May.

The deadline to challenge property values for Class 2, 3, and 4 properties is March 2; the deadline for Class 1 property owners is March 16. Forms are available on the Tax Commission‚Äôs website.

In June, DOF will use the final roll to generate property tax bills for FY 27, which begins on July 1.

DOF also administers several abatement and exemption programs for qualifying homeowners to help lower their property tax bill, including covering senior citizens, veterans, people with disabilities, and clergy, etc.

The agency also noted that it offers payment plans that allow owners to pay their property taxes over time, instead of paying the full amount all at once.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.description:
A stranger slashed a 17-year-old boy in the face with a boxcutter over an accidental bump aboard a Bronx train, according to cops and law-enforcement sources.¬†

The teen was getting on the No. 3 train at the Third Avenue-149th Street Subway station in Mott Haven just before 4 p.m. Dec. 23 when he inadvertently bumped into the other straphanger, sources said.¬†

The jostled rider flew into a rage, hissing, ‚ÄúWhy are you pushing us?‚Äù before cutting the teen on the left side of his face with the weapon, authorities and sources said.¬†

The young victim was taken to Harlem Hospital, where he was listed in stable condition, police said.

The assailant is still on the loose, with police releasing an image of him in hopes of tracking him down.

Despite the year-end violence, city officials touted a 4% drop in major subway crime in 2025 compared to 2024, with robberies down 12.5% ‚Äî an all-time low ‚Äî and shootings falling 62.5%.

Anyone with information on last month‚Äôs alleged attacker is asked to call the NYPD‚Äôs Crime Stoppers Hotline at 1-800-577-TIPS (8477) or for Spanish, 1-888-57-PISTA (74782).¬†

The public can also submit their tips by logging onto the Crime Stoppers website at https://crimestoppers.nypdonline.org/, on X @NYPDTips.
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.title: ËÇØÂ∞ºËø™ÂõΩÈôÖÊú∫Âú∫(JFK) AirTrainËà™Á´ôÊ•ºÊó†ÂÆ∂ÂèØÂΩíËÄÖÊ≥õÊª•Ôºö ‚ÄúÁªùÂØπÊòØÊúÄÁ≥üÁ≥ïÁöÑ‚Äù
item.description:
The AirTrain terminal at JFK Airport has become a hotspot for the homeless, with aggressive vagrants panhandling weary travelers and taking over public bathrooms, while Port Authority cops look the other way, The Post has learned.

Dozens of vagrants ducking the cold weather and shunning unstable conditions at city shelters are instead bedding down inside the busy terminal ‚Äî making the vital hub a nightmare for travelers.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been through this place a bunch of times in the last three years,‚Äù one traveler returning from a family trip to Florida with his fianc√©, who asked to be identified only as Michael, said Monday morning. ‚ÄúThis morning was definitely the worst.

‚ÄúThe second we came in the station there was guys yelling, ‚ÄòCan you buy me something?‚Äô All the cops did nothing while that guy followed us, asking us for money. The entire time, wouldn‚Äôt leave us alone. I told him I had no cash and he was telling me to take something out and pointing to ATMs.‚Äù

Public bathrooms are essentially off limits, others said, because the homeless hunker down in all of the stalls, while some vagrants were spotted snoozing on the floor as suitcase-lugging travelers stroll by.

‚ÄúYes, it‚Äôs a problem,‚Äù complained Arata, 69, who works at a news stand at the terminal. ‚ÄúThere are four of five homeless outside here every day. They confront customers. No, the police do not make them move.‚Äù

The AirTrain hub connects JFK terminals with Long Island Railroad and city subway systems ‚Äî a vital link for Big Apple fliers.

While frigid temperatures have recently driven many of the homeless into the terminal, the vagrants reportedly packed the station even on a milder 50-degree day earlier this month, according to the Daily Mail.

‚ÄúI think the city should definitely do something, Stony Brook University student Aishik Deb told the outlet.

But one homeless man, who identified himself as Griffin, 67, said the city shelter system is the culprit.

‚ÄúThe shelter is no good,‚Äù he said as he stood by two carts near the Sutphin Boulevard entrance Monday. ‚ÄúThey pick you clean. You can‚Äôt even let your shoes dry without somebody taking them. Then you walk around in socks. Now you‚Äôre in trouble.

‚ÄúThis is alright,‚Äù he said of the terminal. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt act the fool and it works out. They don‚Äôt bother anybody here. Getting too crowded now, though. Crazies up there. All night with the arguing and screaming, fighting in the bathroom.‚Äù

The chaotic scene underscores the magnitude of New York City‚Äôs homelessness crisis.

The Empire State had over 158,000 people without a permanent roof over their heads in 2024 ‚Äî a 53% jump from the prior year ‚Äî out of more than 771,000 homeless nationwide, the US Department of Housing and Urban Development said.

HUD‚Äôs report cited pandemic-era eviction backlogs, a lack of affordable housing, rising rent prices, and the migrant crisis as factors driving New York‚Äôs homelessness rate to 81 people per 10,000 residents.

In New York City alone, there were 140,134 homeless people last year, up from 88,025 in 2023, according to Newsday, citing HUD data. More than 130,000 people slept in city shelters in October alone, with thousands more estimated to be living on the streets, according to the Coalition for the Homeless.

Mayor Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs new hands-off approach to the problem isn‚Äôt helping, critics claim.

The Big Apple‚Äôs newly elected Democratic Socialist said last month before taking office that he would halt sweeps of homeless encampments across the five boroughs ‚Äî and even announced after being sworn in that he would roll out 30 public toilets for the homeless.

One MTA employee at the AirTrain terminal quipped, ‚ÄúThis is what I‚Äùm used to.‚Äù

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which oversees JFK and the AirTrain, said in a statement that it works closely with the MTA and other partners to maintain safety and order for travelers and the surrounding community, but is not ‚Äúimmune from the conditions facing the unhoused throughout the region,‚Äù particularly during the winter.

‚ÄúPort Authority Police Department personnel are assigned to the JFK AirTrain portion of the station at Jamaica 24/7 and seek to enforce Port Authority rules and applicable laws, which do not permit use of the station for non-transportation purposes,‚Äù the agency said.

‚ÄúPAPD also conducts regular outreach in conjunction with service providers, including Urban Pathways, to offer assistance and connect unhoused individuals with shelter, social services, and medical or mental health care as appropriate.‚Äù
item.author: Kevin Sheehan, Richard Pollina, Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: ‰ª•‰∏ãÊòØÁé∞Âú®ÈÄöË¥ßËÜ®ËÉÄÁöÑ‰∏•ÈáçÁ®ãÂ∫¶‚ÄîÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶‰∫∫Ê≠£Âú®‰∏≠ÂüéÁöÑÂäûÂÖ¨Ê°åÂâçÂêÉ$ 4ÁÉ§ÂúüË±ÜÔºåÂπ∂Áß∞‰πã‰∏∫ÂçàÈ§ê
item.description:
Potatoes ‚Äî¬†they‚Äôre so hot right now.

As Midtown NYC lunch prices climb ever higher, office workers are taking a bite out of inflation in an unexpectedly tasty way.

At markets, delis and street carts, price-conscious corporate drones are dropping a few dollars each for plain, roasted sweet spuds ‚Äî¬†a rudimentary, rustic-looking nosh that a growing number of fans are happily rawdogging and calling a meal.¬†No frills, no butter, not even salt.

Resorting to such drastic measures might seem more than a little Dickensian, but the spartan sustenance is all the rage nowadays, with cost-conscious epicures lining up everywhere from Rockefeller Center to Koreatown for a yam, bam, thank you ma‚Äôam.

And according to these Big Apple starch seekers, the Stone Age nosh can be surprisingly flavorful.

‚ÄúMmmmm, it tastes like marshmallow,‚Äù raved local foodie Mr. Spice Guy Eats, in a viral video of himself tasting a potato at a popular spot near Penn Station. ‚ÄúThis ‚Ä¶ rocked my world.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so sweet‚Ä¶I feel like to dip it in sugar is like diabetes,‚Äù gushed a popular Instagrammer, who could be seen unwrapping the toasty treat like a banana, after grabbing their go ration from a local supermarket.

What appears as a Soviet-style starvation ration to the naked eye is actually regarded as a cozy winter treat throughout Japan, Korea and China, where they‚Äôre sold everywhere from convenience stores to steel drums on the street corner.

The minimalist munchies have long been prized for their crispy exterior, fluffy belly and natural caramelization that comes from being roasted in its own nectar. They also boast high amounts of important vitamins like beta carotene, vitamin C, and potassium, offering pedestrians a healthy pick-me-up on a frigid day.

Now, typically-naked sweet potatoes are becoming something of a haute meal in the West ‚Äî¬†and not just in pricier-than-ever New York, popping up on social feeds like Courtney Cook‚Äôs.

The Georgia foodfluencer went wildly viral just weeks ago, with a video of her ripping off the top of a spud and shoving a stick of cheese inside ‚Äî¬†a Frankenfood she dubbed a ‚Äúteacher‚Äôs lunch‚Äù in a clip that has snagged over 10 million videos on TikTok.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just so wholesome‚Ä¶.it really gives me energy,‚Äù Cook fawned. ‚ÄúSomething about a potato just fills me up and gives me a lot of satiety.‚Äù

The feeling is being echoed all over Midtown lately, where the tubular meals are being hailed by those stretched by inflation, which has sent the price of even a simple midday repast into the stratosphere.

Those looking to fill their bellies in the commercial heart of the Big Apple are faced with fast food combos that cost nearly $15, bowls of salad sadness running grab-and-go diners nearly $20, and dollar pizza slices that now typically sell for¬†$1.50 or even more, thanks to soaring ingredient costs.

By contrast, depending on where you go, a potato is a super sweet deal ‚Äî¬†at only a few dollars for the fibrous fill-up.

Julie, a hidden cafe on W. 32nd St. at the heart of Koreatown, is one of the most popular hawkers.

Here, potatoes can be seen rotating outside in an oven, like vegan rotisserie.

‚ÄúKorean people really love to roast it,‚Äù Julie‚Äôs proprietor explained in one popular social media video.

Hungry customers will pay $7.99 per pound ‚Äî boiling down to between $2-3 per tater, depending on the size, or around a third of the price of a much less healthy small order of fries at an NYC Five Guys location.

Post taste testers found the potatoes at Julie soft, starchy and hot, but with so much flavor they seemed ready to burst out of their caramelized skin ‚Äî¬†more potato feast than famine.

Julie has been praised by numerous high-profile gourmands online. In one social clip, NYC lifestyle expert and Julie customer Viveca Chow, who boasts over 152,000 followers on Instagram, can be seen chomping a tater the size of a duffel bag, exclaiming, ‚ÄúI love the skin. That‚Äôs glorious.‚Äù

The shop has also been featured in an NYC ‚ÄúSweet Potato Crawl‚Äù by online food influencers Katherine Lee and Brandon McDonald.

Sweet potatoes are also a staple at Hmart, a popular Korean supermarket down the street. Here, the potato bellies tasted especially pillowy and sweet ‚Äî¬†with hints of candied apple.

Bonus points for how they functioned like hot water bottles, warming frozen hands during the sudden January cold snap.

At Hmart, you‚Äôll pay $6-7 for a two-pack depending on the size ‚Äî less than half the price of a typical roughage bowl at Sweetgreen.

Further uptown, a bustling gourmet deli in a gleaming office tower across from Radio City Music Hall is the last place you‚Äôd expect to see slinging naked potatoes out of an oven.

But in the center of the upscale Duke Eatery, they‚Äôre given pride of place ‚Äî¬†with customers paying just $6.99 per pound, if they can even get their hands on the popular item, which often sells out during the lunch rush.

Here, the taters are exceptionally large ‚Äî¬†one is a snack, two is carb-aggedon.

Not every purveyor is of Korean provenance, however.

Across Sixth Avenue in the Rock Center concourse, a branch of Miznon, a Mediterranean fast-casual chain from Israeli chef Eyal Shani, also serves a renowned roasted sweet potato ‚Äî¬†an affordable option on the otherwise spendier menu.

Often, office workers wait in line to get one of the potatoes, workers told The Post, but they‚Äôre frequently left disappointed ‚Äî¬†as the hot commodities frequently sell out.

Compared to the rest, Miznon‚Äôs offering is downright luxurious, roasted in honey and served whole with a side of sour cream ‚Äî¬†a sweet, gourmet take on the trend.

At $5 for one and $9 for two, this one tips into slightly pricier territory ‚Äî¬†but it‚Äôs downright delicious.
item.author: Ben Cost

item.title: Kianna UnderwoodÁöÑNickelodeonÊºîÂëòËØïÂõæÂØªÊ±ÇÂ•πÁöÑÂ∏ÆÂä©‚ÄîË≠¶ÊñπÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ËÇá‰∫ãÈÄÉÈÄ∏ÊÅêÊÄñ‰∫ã‰ª∂‰∏≠ÂèëÁé∞SUV
item.description:
One of Kianna Underwood‚Äôs ‚ÄúAll That‚Äù castmates tried to muster help for the down-and-out former Nickelodeon child star years before a hit-and-run driver killed her in Brooklyn ‚Äî as sources revealed Monday that police found the car behind the horrific crash.

Angelique Bates posted an emotional Instagram video in November 2023 alerting her fellow ‚ÄúAll That‚Äù alums that Underwood ‚Äî who appeared on the children‚Äôs comedy show‚Äôs final season in the early aughts ‚Äî was homeless.

‚ÄúI was not aware that she has been in New York homeless,‚Äù Bates said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand why no one‚Äôs talking about it.‚Äù

Bates, an original cast member along with current ‚ÄúSaturday Night Live‚Äù star Kenan Thompson, pleaded with the show‚Äôs cast and Nickelodeon executives to make a plan to get Underwood help.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs like literally one of the babies,‚Äù she said, referring to Underwood‚Äôs late arrival on the show.

Underwood appeared in several ‚ÄúAll That‚Äù episodes, ending in 2005.

But the former child star, 33, remained homeless, becoming a frequent sight on the Brownsville streets where she‚Äôd eventually die after being struck by two as-yet-unidentified hit-and-run drivers on Jan. 16.

The first runaway motorist driving a Ford SUV plowed into Underwood as she crossed Pitkin Boulevard at Mother Gaston Boulevard in the crosswalk against the signal, sources said.

Sources said the SUV pulled into the opposing lane of traffic to drive around a stopped vehicle, only to ram into Underwood.

Underwood‚Äôs body flew across the intersection, where the SUV‚Äôs driver stopped before driving away, sources said. Another vehicle ‚Äî a black and gray sedan ‚Äî then ran over Underwood and dragged her several hundred feet, according to sources.

NYPD investigators tracked down and impounded the Ford SUV that first struck Underwood, but are still gathering evidence to identify its driver, sources said.

The fatal hit-and-run inspired an outpouring of grief for Underwood, including from Bates.

‚ÄúY‚Äôall have no idea how much this one hurts‚Ä¶Sick to my stomach‚Ä¶.So many people failed baby girl,‚Äù she posted after Underwood‚Äôs death.

‚Äî Additional reporting by Amanda Woods
item.author: Joe Marino, Matt Troutman

item.title: Palisades CenterË¥≠Áâ©‰∏≠ÂøÉÂú®ÁªèÂéÜ‰∫ÜÂ§öÂπ¥ÁöÑË¥¢Âä°Âõ∞Â¢ÉÂêéÂâçÂæÄÊãçÂçñÂå∫
item.description:
It‚Äôs the region‚Äôs biggest going-out-of-business sale.

The Palisades Center, a 2.2 million-square-foot megamall in Rockland County ‚Äî and one of the biggest malls in America ‚Äî is due to go on the auction block next month for an estimated $463 million, according to reports.

The once-bustling retail hub has been targeted for foreclosure for nearly three years because of more than $418 million in unpaid debts that have hung over the property‚Äôs owners since 2016, lohud.com said.

Despite the loan changing hands between several creditors in recent years, the mall‚Äôs owners finally ran out of time and are gearing up to sell the property to the highest bidder in a Manhattan courtroom Feb. 4.

The mall was originally developed by The Pyramid Companies and is now owned by a real estate consortium made up of EklecCo NewCo LLC, Queens Comic‚Äôs NewCo LLC, Riesling Associates, and Three J‚Äôs Family Trust, according to the reports.

‚ÄúThis is a straightforward foreclosure, like if you had a house and you didn‚Äôt pay the mortgage,‚Äù bankruptcy lawyer Michael Koplen told News12 Westchester. ‚ÄúEventually there‚Äôs a foreclosure, and that‚Äôs what happened here. But of course, the numbers are much bigger than a house.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the only thing that I think could happen here, with the exception of an appeal being filed and then a stay against proceedings,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut no notice of appeal has been filed that I see on the docket.‚Äù

The massive mall opened in West Nyack on March 4, 1998, to much hoopla. Olympic figure skater Nancy Kerrigan was on hand to inaugurate a fourth-floor skating rink at the mega center.

In its heyday, there were four anchor stores and a slew of retail shops and more than 225 shopping, eating and entertainment stops that drew as many as 24 million shoppers a year, according to the mall‚Äôs website.

But the mall started to get into a financial hole by 2016, when the owners took out a $418 million loan.

During the COVID pandemic in 2020, the owners got an extension on the loan but were still unable to pay it off by its due date of 2022, lohud.com said.

Wilmington Trust, which owned the loan, sued to foreclose in 2023. While the bank then sold off the loan at a loss to another creditor, a notice of sale for the entire mall was finally send out Jan. 7.

Despite the grim news, George Hoehmann, the supervisor of Clarkstown, which includes the hamlet of West Nyack, isn‚Äôt throwing in the towel yet.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean that it‚Äôs actually going to be a sale,‚Äù he told News12. ‚ÄúThere looks like there‚Äôs going to be a court hearing beginning of February, and then we‚Äôll see what happens from there.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a well-performing asset, and we‚Äôre confident that it will have a bright future going forward,‚Äù Hoehmann added. ‚ÄúWhoever is going to end up owning it, they‚Äôll be talking with the town. It‚Äôs zoned as a mall.‚Äù
item.author: Jorge Fitz-Gibbon
